Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Commercialization of a Novel Titanium Alloy Additive Manufacturing Process
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is based in furthering the innovation in an already innovative additive manufacturing (AM) industry. This proposal represents up to $120M in potential revenue within a ten year period in an AM process that will be orders of magnitude cheaper than competitive processes. With regards to a societal impact, additive manufacturing represents a paradigm shift in manufacturing and a significant opportunity to bring manufacturing and jobs back into this country. The economic and environmental implications of the additive manufacturing opportunity are thus incredibly vast for America and for the world. Local manufacturing has implications for both the economy and the environment. The Selectively Inhibited Sintering technology potentially represents a further refinement in accessibility to this burgeoning technological field, especially for small to medium sized companies that cannot afford the use of incredibly expensive competitive equipment.


This project will implement a disruptive additive manufacturing technology. The core concept behind the Selectively Inhibited Sintering process is the prevention of selected segments of each powder layer from sintering. In the current metal process, a commercial piezoelectric print head is utilized to deposit a liquid inhibitor solution at the part boundary of each layer. Once all of the layers have been completed, the entire part is removed from the machine and bulk sintered in a conventional sintering furnace. The inhibitor at the part boundary decomposes into hard particles that retard the sintering process. The metal powder particles in this region are prevented from fusing, allowing for removal of inhibited boundary sections and revealing of the completed part. Successful completion of this project will potentially result in a paradigm shift in the future of metallic AM for hard-to-manufacture industrial parts. Targeted materials are high temperature metallic alloys such as iron, steel, or titanium which are widely used in many industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of the proposed research was to develop a high performance metallic 3D printing solution called the ‘Dream Builder’. This revolutionary 3D printer was based on additive manufacturing patents originally developed at the University of Southern California. This innovative technology allows for orders of magnitude reduction in cost when fabricating 3D printed metallic parts.

The core concept behind the SIS process is the prevention of selected segments of each powder layer from sintering. This phenomenon, which is called the inhibition process, can be achieved in one of four ways: macroscopic mechanical inhibition, microscopic mechanical inhibition, chemical inhibition, or thermal inhibition. In the current metal process, a commercial piezoelectric print head is utilized to deposit a liquid inhibitor solution at the part boundary of each layer. Once all of the layers have been completed, the entire part is removed from the machine and bulk sintered in a conventional sintering furnace. In the furnace, the inhibitor at the part boundary decomposes into hard particles that retard the sintering process by way of microscopic mechanical inhibition. The particles in this region are prevented from fusing, allowing for removal of inhibited boundary sections and revealing of the completed part. Similarly, high temperature particles can be deposited directly via a hypodermic needle implanted into the powder bed. These high temperature particles could also serve as a barrier at the perimeter of the part, separating inside from outside.

As a result of the NSF SBIR Phase I program funding, the SoliDreams team was able to overcome all proposed technical hurdles and objectives, culminating in the prototype of one the world's first industrial metal 3D printers at a consumer level price point (Figure 1). This prototype was used to create a multitde of 316L stainless steel parts (Figure 2). This process represents the world's first high resolution, low-cost additive manufacturing process for metallic parts. In addition, the research prototype represents one of the world's first layerless AM proceses for metallic parts, an innovation only made possible through the resources made available by the National Science Foundation.

This NSF funded research represents a fundamental shift in the cost structure of metallic additive manufacturing in three important ways moving forward. First, the capital costs associated with installing a metallic AM machine has been dramatically reduced. Second, the maintenance costs associated with a low cost machine have also been reduced. Finally, this implementation of a metallic 3D printer is generally material independent. In other words, off-the-shelf metallic powders can quite easily be adopted for use with little effort.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2016
Modified by: Matthew R Petros
